narratives.question_text: Please identify the teaching assistant with whom you interacted most closely _____________________ .
comments: Instructor: Henry Glick  Henry Glick
Instructor: Henry Glick  Henry Glick
Instructor: Henry Glick  Henry Glick
Instructor: Henry Glick  Henry Glick.
Instructor: Henry Glick  Henry Glick
Instructor: Henry Glick  Henry was a good TA however it was difficult to talk to him outside class hours due to our conflicting schedules.
Instructor: Henry Glick  Henry Glick. He was excellent!

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: Instructor: Henry Glick  He provides excellent review of our homeworks which includes comments besides the grades. The comments were very helpful for improving our work as we progressed along.
Instructor: Henry Glick  Henry was an excellent teaching fellow. He was quick to answer questions by email, active in developing extra resources for our use, and generally very knowledgeable.

Instructor: Henry Glick  Henry was always available at office hours to provide insight on the upcoming homework assignments, things brought up in class, or other R-related topics. He answered emails promptly with detailed explanations, that were very helpful.
Instructor: Henry Glick  Strength - rapid return of assignments, with useful feedback.
Instructor: Henry Glick  Henry was really responsive to all my questions in person and over email. He really made sure we understood what we were learning and how to use the programs properly.
Instructor: Henry Glick  My teaching assistant was accessible and knowledgeable in the course.

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: About the course was very helpful, and I learned a lot from all different techniques that we explored. At times I had a really hard time with the mathematical components of the class I don't know whether that time could have been spent doing something more related to practical uses of the models or making our understanding of their inner workings a little bit easier. I liked it in class we went through examples and actually saw how the models were working those are my favorite discussions. I think would've been nice to have had a question-and-answer session briefly following each homework being turned in, because that's when the materials fresh in our minds we can ask relevant questions.
I highly recommend this course to any student who wants solid foundation in statistics.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Assignments and projects were always well-applied, with a clear reason for doing the assignment. It was easy to frame my thoughts on each assignment in a way that made sense to me and my research. The course was also very well organized with a sensible progression in topics.

The best aspects of this course were deftly the homework assignments and having the opportunity to practice modeling on a regular basis. I enjoyed working with the data sets and practicing the skills, though at times it did require going to see Henry to make things work properly.
Regression is an important topic to scientific consideration of the environment. One is hard-pressed to think about working with environment without comprehension of this material.

The best aspect of this course was hands-on experience in practicing the different regression models and how to use it in R software. Tim really wants to make sure you understand it and cares about his students.
Assignments and theoretical concepts. The fact that this course is run in R which is free and open source.
Instructor's material and teaching.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Nothing

Lecture's were very theory-heavy. Theory by itself is not bad, but too much of it made the lectures dull and, at times, very difficult to understand. A good understanding of matrix algebra is essential to understanding the lectures, but too little time is spent on actually developing the skills necessary to understand the notation and associated theory.

I think perhaps working to make the in class portion a bit more engaging would be really helpful. The notes are extremely well-written and helpful, and I constantly return to them, but at times I feel like I get more out of reading the notes on my own then by sitting in class hearing them. So perhaps there's some way to apply the notes to the class lecture? Not sure what the best way to go about this is.
Streamlining the information from each lecture note series. A more concise set of instructions, particularly for the handling of r code, would be greatly appreciated.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: This is one of the most useful course that i have taken which i know , i will be applying in my work.
Very helpful for my research interests. I feel much more knowledgeable about regression than I did coming in.

This course is really broad my horizons in terms of understanding modeling which is a huge part of watershed science. Even though it's only one branch of modeling it opens windows to new techniques and thoughts. I thought this course provided a really good framework for understanding other models too.
Good fit. Statistical consideration of environmental data is essential to work in the environment.

This course is perfect for those people looking for a way to study regression statistics within the forestry school at a lightly advanced level than those offered by the basic courses. It is very heavily reliant on examples from forestry but the practical applications of the skills learned here extend far beyond it. Perhaps more examples from other disciplines would be useful in providing context for students.
As a research student, I find the course very helpful in obtaining robust foundation in statistics for my research work.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I was specifically interested in learning about regression modelling

I took this course because I knew modeling would be important in my research, and using R is also an important skill. I think I will use a lot of these techniques in my research when I have my data next spring, so in designing my proposals and plans for research this semester this course has been really helpful.
Statistical consideration of environmental data is essential to work in the environment. Previous statistical courses I took were week in regression work.
I wanted a review and improve my regression skills. I also wanted to learn more regression modelling to help me analyze my own current and future data.
Initally curious and seemed a good fit for my areas of interest.
I wanted a solid background in statistics for my research work.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Very much
Met my expectations.
YES! Above and beyond what I expected!
Yes.
I learned a lot of different types of regression models, how and when to use them, and improved my R skills.
Yes. It has been most illuminating.
Yes, it did.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Read the notes first to understand the concept and then refer to textbooks.
Read up on your matrix algebra.

Just know that once you get the hang of it and apply enough time to work on the homework assignments you'll do well. But you have to be able to plan ahead and be comfortable being frustrated sometimes. Using the teaching fellow is particularly helpful, but you need to schedule yourself so that you can do that accordingly.

Have some background in statistics. Be prepared to learn the R statistics programming language while learning regression -- this can be a challenge. If you already know R, by all means, jump in! Prof. G. is fantastic!

Think of the class as already flipped. All the material is present and the best way to experience the course is to read the notes beforehand and ask questions on bits you didn't understand in class. Tim is extremely helpful when it comes to responding to questions and is very encouraging.
I highly recommend this course to all students who want to take this course.
